<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 729, 635]]<|/det|>

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A cylinder is suspended from the end of a string. The cylinder is stationary in water with the axis of the cylinder vertical, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 300, 589, 319]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 331, 920, 381]]<|/det|>
The cylinder has weight \(0.84 \text{N}\), height \(h\) and a circular cross-section of diameter \(0.031 \text{m}\). The density of the water is \(1.0 \times 10^{3} \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\). The difference between the pressures on the top and bottom faces of the cylinder is \(520 \text{Pa}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 394, 183, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 394, 500, 413]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 532, 920, 549]]<|/det|>
<form>h = .................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 564, 181, 583]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 564, 645, 583]]<|/det|>
Show that the upthrust acting on the cylinder is \(0.39 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 718, 920, 737]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 750, 181, 769]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 875, 920, 893]]<|/det|>
<form>T = .................................................... N [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
The string is now used to move the cylinder in **(a)** vertically upwards through the water. The variation with time \(t\) of the velocity \(v\) of the cylinder is shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
The cylinder in **(b)** is released from the string at time \(t = 4.0 \text{s}\). The cylinder falls, from rest, vertically downwards through the water. Assume that the upthrust acting on the cylinder remains constant as it falls.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A spring is fixed at one end and is compressed by applying a force to the other end. The variation of the force \(F\) acting on the spring with its compression \(x\) is shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 920, 354]]<|/det|>
A compression of \(0.045 \text{m}\) is produced when a force \(F_{1}\) acts on the spring. The spring has a spring constant of \(800 \text{N} \text{m}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 180, 383]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 365, 313, 383]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 472, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
<form>F_{1} = .................................................... N [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 504, 181, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 504, 920, 539]]<|/det|>
Use Fig. 3.1 to show that, for a compression of \(0.045 \text{m}\), the elastic potential energy of the spring is \(0.81 \text{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 660, 920, 678]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 691, 146, 710]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 691, 920, 755]]<|/det|>
A child's toy uses the spring in **(a)** to launch a ball of mass \(0.020\mathrm{kg}\) vertically into the air. The ball is initially held against one end of the spring which has a compression of \(0.045\mathrm{m}\). The spring is then released to launch the ball. The kinetic energy of the ball as it leaves the toy is \(0.72 \mathrm{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 769, 181, 787]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 768, 920, 802]]<|/det|>
The toy converts the elastic potential energy of the spring into the kinetic energy of the ball. Use the information in **(a)**(ii) to calculate the percentage efficiency of this conversion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[487, 910, 920, 928]]<|/det|>
<form>efficiency = .................................................... %

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 500, 880, 519]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 532, 183, 551]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 860, 920, 878]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 776, 89]]<|/det|>
When there is air resistance, the ball takes time \(T\) to move from A to B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether the time taken for the ball to move from A to its maximum height will be more than, less than or equal to time \(T\) if there is **no** air resistance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 190, 920, 207]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 212, 920, 230]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A rigid plank is used to make a ramp between two different horizontal levels of ground, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 112, 747, 345]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 355, 591, 373]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 386, 920, 450]]<|/det|>
Point A at one end of the plank rests on the lower level of the ground. A force acts on, and is perpendicular to, the plank at point B. The plank is held in equilibrium by a rope that connects point D on the plank to the ground. The plank has a weight that may be considered to act from its centre of gravity C.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 464, 920, 498]]<|/det|>
The rope is perpendicular to the plank and has tension \(T.\) The plank is at an angle of \(38^{\circ}\) to the vertical.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 510, 866, 529]]<|/det|>
The forces and the distances along the plank of points A, B, C and D are shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 542, 146, 560]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 541, 818, 560]]<|/det|>
Show that the component of the weight that is perpendicular to the plank is \(59 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 653, 920, 670]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 683, 148, 702]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 682, 722, 701]]<|/det|>
By taking moments about end A of the plank, calculate the tension \(T.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 898, 920, 917]]<|/det|>
<form>T = .................................................... N [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 925, 920, 942]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[824, 945, 920, 962]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Turn over

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Microwaves with the same wavelength and amplitude are emitted in phase from two sources X and Y, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 112, 860, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 268, 591, 288]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 300, 920, 350]]<|/det|>
A microwave detector is moved along a path parallel to the line joining X and Y. An interference pattern is detected. A central intensity maximum is located at point A and there is an adjacent intensity minimum at point B. The microwaves have a wavelength of \(0.040 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 362, 146, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 362, 584, 381]]<|/det|>
Calculate the frequency, in GHz, of the microwaves.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[482, 534, 920, 553]]<|/det|>
<form>frequency = ............................................... GHz [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 566, 146, 584]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 566, 524, 584]]<|/det|>
For the waves arriving at point B, determine:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 597, 183, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 597, 351, 615]]<|/det|>
the path difference

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 689, 920, 708]]<|/det|>
<form>path difference = ................................................... m [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 721, 181, 740]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 721, 371, 740]]<|/det|>
the phase difference.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 813, 920, 833]]<|/det|>
<form>phase difference = ................................................... Â° [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
The amplitudes of the waves from the sources are changed. This causes a change in the amplitude of the waves arriving at point A. At this point, the amplitude of the wave arriving from source X is doubled and the amplitude of the wave arriving from source Y is also doubled.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 787, 152]]<|/det|>
Describe the effect, if any, on the intensity of the central maximum at point A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 258, 146, 276]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
Describe the effect, if any, on the positions of the central intensity maximum and the adjacent intensity minimum due to the following separate changes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 304, 183, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 303, 623, 322]]<|/det|>
The separation of the sources X and Y is increased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 365, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 396, 181, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 396, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
The phase difference between the microwaves emitted by the sources X and Y changes to \(180^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 504, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 504, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 792, 92]]<|/det|>
A network of three resistors of resistances \(R_{1}, R_{2}\) and \(R_{3}\) is shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 100, 683, 273]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 286, 532, 305]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 317, 920, 352]]<|/det|>
The individual currents in the resistors are \(I_{1}, I_{2}\) and \(I_{3}\). The total current in the combination of resistors is \(I\) and the potential difference across the combination is \(V.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 364, 682, 383]]<|/det|>
Show that the combined resistance \(R\) of the network is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 386, 591, 419]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_1} + \frac{1}{R_2} + \frac{1}{R_3}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 565, 920, 584]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 597, 146, 615]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 597, 920, 631]]<|/det|>
A battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) 8.0V and internal resistance \(r\) is connected to three resistors X, Y and Z, as shown in Fig. 6.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[329, 636, 667, 875]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 889, 534, 908]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Resistor Y has a resistance of \(16\Omega\). The current in resistor X is \(0.49\mathrm{A}\) and the current in resistor Y is \(0.45\mathrm{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 243, 134]]<|/det|>
Calculate:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 180, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 149, 400, 166]]<|/det|>
the current in the battery

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[505, 241, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
<form>current = ....................................................... A [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 272, 180, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 272, 507, 291]]<|/det|>
the internal resistance \(r\) of the battery.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 411, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
<form>r = .................................................... $\Omega$ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 443, 144, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 920, 476]]<|/det|>
Resistors X and Y in Fig. 6.2 are made from wires of the same material and cross-sectional area. The average drift speed of the free electrons in X is \(2.1 \times 10^{-4} \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 488, 655, 507]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average drift speed \(v\) of the free electrons in Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 662, 920, 681]]<|/det|>
<form>v = ................................................. \(\text{ms}^{-1}\) [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 693, 148, 712]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 693, 751, 712]]<|/det|>
Resistor Z in Fig. 6.2 is replaced by a new resistor of smaller resistance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 724, 850, 743]]<|/det|>
State and explain the effect, if any, on the terminal potential difference of the battery.

similarity: ...................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 149, 920, 166]]<|/det|>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
Fig. 7.1 shows an electron in an electric field, in a vacuum, at an instant when the electron is stationary.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 218, 747, 364]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 377, 532, 395]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 7.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 408, 181, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 408, 920, 441]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 7.1, draw an arrow to show the direction of the electric force acting on the stationary electron.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 422, 920, 441]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 454, 181, 473]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 454, 757, 472]]<|/det|>
The electric field causes the electron to move from its initial position.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 485, 920, 518]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 625, 920, 644]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 655, 178, 673]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 655, 920, 688]]<|/det|>
A stationary \(\alpha\) -particle is now placed in the same electric field at the same initial position that was occupied by the electron.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 702, 920, 735]]<|/det|>
Compare the initial electric force acting on the \(\alpha\) -particle with the initial electric force that acted on the electron.
